content: This morning in the Florida waters off Key West, engineers are planting and detonating explosives aboard the U.S.S. Vandenberg, the culmination of almost a decade of legal wrangling, to create a new "artificial reef" for divers to enjoy. I must say I'm pleased on many levels, the least of which being that I am currently in the process of relocating to the Keys for work as a SCUBA Instructor....(I've been teaching SCUBA for 16 years). I am encouraging all certified divers (and if your not certified, THAT little detail can be fixed) to come down and enjoy the new shipwreck and the surrounding reefs that are in the Florida Keys. I would consider it an honor to assist in any way possible, any United States Military Veterans who want to experience the underwater beauty of the Florida Keys.... Please do not take this as a solicitation, for it is not meant to be so. I'm just getting the word out. It's just that SCUBA is my life, and I wholeheartedly believe it's one of the best things a person can persue as a hobby. (Or in my case, a career) See ya in The Keys..... Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI Instructor #160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: Did you ever dive the Spiegel Grove up off of Key Largo near Carysfort Reef? Because the sunk it in such shallow water, they say it's a much more safer dive than the USCG Cutters Bibb or Duane near Molasses Reef. Don I left the Keys for Cabo in March 2000, so I missed the sinking of the Spiegel Grove goin' down....I have dove the U.S.G.C. Duane, the Thunderbolt, The Eagle, and The wreckage of the U.S.S. Alexander, and am WAY STOKED to do them again..... When I was working on the Big Island of Hawaii I spoke to a diver who was present on the dive to the Spiegel Grove when those divers died on it a few years ago, he said the Spiegel was "deceptive and a dive could go bad in a heartbeat (as is the case on any shipwreck if one is not properly trained or careful) and yet I still can't wait to dive it...The U.S.C.G.C Duane is a GREAT dive, (when the conditions are right) and I'm exited as all GET OUT to see a new wreck to go down...Aside from teaching, when it comes to SCUBA, wreck diving is my THING...My ex said I have a screw loose....What do you expect? I'm a SCUBA Instructor... See you at Captain Tony's in Key West! (Or the Green Parrot, or Turtle Kraals, 1st round is on me ! Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI Instructor #160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE USS Spiegel Grove

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: Sound's like fun. I wish I knew how to dive! I lived in the Key Largo area from '85 to '01. This one was caught a mile or two from Molasses Reef. Don Worked at UNEXO in Freeport, Grand bahama 95-96...I was the guy in the chain mail suit feeding the reef sharks by hand...Did a cage trip to the Farrallon Islands in '98....Froze my azz but saw a couple Great Whites....Had a six ft. White Tip Reef Shark LAY ON ME in a lava tube over on the Big Island...Counted coup on a 12 ft. Tiger (and have the video to prove it) on the Big Island as well....Don't let the myth that Hollywood perpetuates about sharks scare you out of the water, brah....There are more people killed each year by "domesticated" pig attacks than by sharks....Come on down!!! I was a NAUI Instructor from '93-'98, but in the Dive Biz it's easier to score jobs as a PADI Instructor..... Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"

content: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. I had active Open Water, Wreck and Cave Diving certs...I let them lapse from living in the dry Arizona desert these last couple of decades and never diving once during that time. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer.
reply: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. I had active Open Water, Wreck and Cave Diving certs...I let them lapse from living in the dry Arizona desert these last couple of decades and never diving once during that time. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer.
title: Sink the Vandenberg!

content: While diving in the Diego Garcia lagoon with my dive buddy Dale "Zuke" Zukowski, we saw "Hector the Horrible", a huge resident hammerhead shark no one had warned us about. By hugging the verticals and staying as close to the bottom as we could, we avoided drawing the big shark's interest, and we also decided we did not belong diving in that particular place from that point on. I also dove plane wreck-infested Truk Lagoon, Florida's Pennekamp Park, Hanauma Bay, Hawaii, off Grande Island in Subic/Manila Bay, Philippines, off Perth, Australia, plus the Great Barrier Reef, and humble Point Loma @ San Diego, and in 58-degree water there! The moray eels living below the kelp beds off the point at about 60 feet didn't mind the cold water at all. They were looking for food in the diver's game bags---abalones, etc.
reply: While diving in the Diego Garcia lagoon with my dive buddy Dale "Zuke" Zukowski, we saw "Hector the Horrible", a huge resident hammerhead shark no one had warned us about. By hugging the verticals and staying as close to the bottom as we could, we avoided drawing the big shark's interest, and we also decided we did not belong diving in that particular place from that point on. I also dove plane wreck-infested Truk Lagoon, Florida's Pennekamp Park, Hanauma Bay, Hawaii, off Grande Island in Subic/Manila Bay, Philippines, off Perth, Australia, plus the Great Barrier Reef, and humble Point Loma @ San Diego, and in 58-degree water there! The moray eels living below the kelp beds off the point at about 60 feet didn't mind the cold water at all. They were looking for food in the diver's game bags---abalones, etc.

content: quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. I had active Open Water, Wreck and Cave Diving certs...I let them lapse from living in the dry Arizona desert these last couple of decades and never diving once during that time. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer. The biggest difference is that in the NAUI Openwater I course, a student is taught basic dive rescue(bringing a diver simulating unconciousness to the surface, and initiate rescue breathing) while in the PADI system of diver training that particular exercise is not taught until the Rescue Diver Course....NAUI courses also have a bigger emphasis on snorkeling skills at the surface....Also; during the NAUI divemaster course, a Divemaster candidate is required to do an 880 yd. snorkel with mask, fins, bcd(no tank) and weightbelt in 18 min...The PADI DM course requires an DM candidate to snorkel 800 yds in mask, snorkel, and fins, NO TIME LIMIT..... If you were NAUI certified, it is not necessary to re-certify....You certification should be on file and your card easily replaced just contact NAUI HQ (they are located in Tampa, I believe)...I would highly recommend a refresher course...They are taught at pretty much any dive shop..Regardless of Certification Agency....Hope that helps brah, now dust off the gear AND GO GET WET!!!!! There is another distinction..(some dive instructor humor for you) NAUI= Not Another Underwater Idiot PADI= Pay And Dive Immediately Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI#160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"
quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? If you were NAUI certified, it is not necessary to re-certify....You certification should be on file and your card easily replaced just contact NAUI HQ (they are located in Tampa, I believe)...I would highly recommend a refresher course...They are taught at pretty much any dive shop..Regardless of Certification Agency....Hope that helps brah, now dust off the gear AND GO GET WET!!!!! There is another distinction..(some dive instructor humor for you) NAUI= Not Another Underwater Idiot PADI= Pay And Dive Immediately Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI#160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"

content: I am still dismayed that DOD/the Navy somehow saw fit to consign the USS Belleau Wood(LHA-3) to the same fate as these other ships; sinking them. The cost to buy foreign steel and to build new ships is climbing fast, yet our lunkhead 'leaders' somehow see fit to literally THROW AWAY and DESTROY MILLIONS of dollars worth of that costly, (and in the case of LHA-3) still viable steel and technology. The Navy has many truly OLD, no-longer-viable ships it can sink and use for artificial reefs, instead of its sinking such versatile multi-purpose ships as the USS Belleau Wood, a large, relatively young and healthy 27 years old, 40,000-ton amphibious assault ship. The wa$te is truly staggering!! -LHA-3 Rusty, USS Belleau Wood (LHA-3) Plankowner, 1978-1984 R.I.P., USS Belleau Wood!

content: I can tell you that the crown-of-thorns starfish decimates living coral polyps and reef colonies, so the artificial reefs/ships are 'iffy' at best. If the reefs don't form or remain naturally, or are killed off by natural enemies like the crown-of thorns, then the ships are just hulks, home to plants, fish and other denizens of the seas, and places for adventurous scuba divers to explore.
reply: I can tell you that the crown-of-thorns starfish decimates living coral polyps and reef colonies, so the artificial reefs/ships are 'iffy' at best. content: GWG, I agree with you. I inquired about this, the reply was, "It cost more to scrap old ships than sink them as artificial reefs". I suggested they could do as exactly as you said, I recieved no reply. The US trying to be the good guy, buys inferior crap from China and other countries. The steel industry in the states would provide quality steel and employ thousands of American jobs. The steel industry is like others, it's all about PROFIT and GREED. Get cheap labor, screw quality, the fat cats at the top are usless baggage are getting huge incomes, while paying for cheap labor. Fire the fat cats, retain one fat cat, pay him/her an hourly wage. Pay him/ her a few dollars more than those who do the real work! Remember, the recent event of sheet rock purchased from China that was used in new homes? It made people sick and made their homes uninhabitable, once again, profit and greed. Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

title: Sink the Vandenberg!

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: Sound's like fun. I wish I knew how to dive! I lived in the Key Largo area from '85 to '01. Though I was NAUI certified, I only dove a couple of times and snorkeled offshore maybe a few time as well. It was these guys that took my enthusiasm away. This one was caught a mile or two from Molasses Reef. Don Worked at UNEXO in Freeport, Grand bahama 95-96...I was the guy in the chain mail suit feeding the reef sharks by hand...Did a cage trip to the Farrallon Islands in '98....Froze my azz but saw a couple Great Whites....Had a six ft. White Tip Reef Shark LAY ON ME in a lava tube over on the Big Island...Counted coup on a 12 ft. Tiger (and have the video to prove it) on the Big Island as well....Don't let the myth that Hollywood perpetuates about sharks scare you out of the water, brah....There are more people killed each year by "domesticated" pig attacks than by sharks....Come on down!!! I was a NAUI Instructor from '93-'98, but in the Dive Biz it's easier to score jobs as a PADI Instructor..... Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"

content: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. I had active Open Water, Wreck and Cave Diving certs...I let them lapse from living in the dry Arizona desert these last couple of decades and never diving once during that time. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer.
reply: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. I had active Open Water, Wreck and Cave Diving certs...I let them lapse from living in the dry Arizona desert these last couple of decades and never diving once during that time. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer.
title: Sink the Vandenberg!

content: While diving in the Diego Garcia lagoon with my dive buddy Dale "Zuke" Zukowski, we saw "Hector the Horrible", a huge resident hammerhead shark no one had warned us about. By hugging the verticals and staying as close to the bottom as we could, we avoided drawing the big shark's interest, and we also decided we did not belong diving in that particular place from that point on. I also dove plane wreck-infested Truk Lagoon, Florida's Pennekamp Park, Hanauma Bay, Hawaii, off Grande Island in Subic/Manila Bay, Philippines, off Perth, Australia, plus the Great Barrier Reef, and humble Point Loma @ San Diego, and in 58-degree water there! The moray eels living below the kelp beds off the point at about 60 feet didn't mind the cold water at all. They were looking for food in the diver's game bags---abalones, etc.
reply: While diving in the Diego Garcia lagoon with my dive buddy Dale "Zuke" Zukowski, we saw "Hector the Horrible", a huge resident hammerhead shark no one had warned us about. By hugging the verticals and staying as close to the bottom as we could, we avoided drawing the big shark's interest, and we also decided we did not belong diving in that particular place from that point on. I also dove plane wreck-infested Truk Lagoon, Florida's Pennekamp Park, Hanauma Bay, Hawaii, off Grande Island in Subic/Manila Bay, Philippines, off Perth, Australia, plus the Great Barrier Reef, and humble Point Loma @ San Diego, and in 58-degree water there! The moray eels living below the kelp beds off the point at about 60 feet didn't mind the cold water at all. They were looking for food in the diver's game bags---abalones, etc.
title: Sink the Vandenberg!

content: quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. I had active Open Water, Wreck and Cave Diving certs...I let them lapse from living in the dry Arizona desert these last couple of decades and never diving once during that time. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer. The biggest difference is that in the NAUI Openwater I course, a student is taught basic dive rescue(bringing a diver simulating unconciousness to the surface, and initiate rescue breathing) while in the PADI system of diver training that particular exercise is not taught until the Rescue Diver Course....NAUI courses also have a bigger emphasis on snorkeling skills at the surface....Also; during the NAUI divemaster course, a Divemaster candidate is required to do an 880 yd. snorkel with mask, fins, bcd(no tank) and weightbelt in 18 min...The PADI DM course requires an DM candidate to snorkel 800 yds in mask, snorkel, and fins, NO TIME LIMIT..... If you were NAUI certified, it is not necessary to re-certify....You certification should be on file and your card easily replaced just contact NAUI HQ (they are located in Tampa, I believe)...I would highly recommend a refresher course...They are taught at pretty much any dive shop..Regardless of Certification Agency....Hope that helps brah, now dust off the gear AND GO GET WET!!!!! There is another distinction..(some dive instructor humor for you) NAUI= Not Another Underwater Idiot PADI= Pay And Dive Immediately Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI#160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"
quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer.

If you were NAUI certified, it is not necessary to re-certify....You certification should be on file and your card easily replaced just contact NAUI HQ (they are located in Tampa, I believe)...I would highly recommend a refresher course...They are taught at pretty much any dive shop..Regardless of Certification Agency....Hope that helps brah, now dust off the gear AND GO GET WET!!!!! There is another distinction..(some dive instructor humor for you) NAUI= Not Another Underwater Idiot PADI= Pay And Dive Immediately Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI#160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"

content: I am still dismayed that DOD/the Navy somehow saw fit to consign the USS Belleau Wood(LHA-3) to the same fate as these other ships; sinking them. The cost to buy foreign steel and to build new ships is climbing fast, yet our lunkhead 'leaders' somehow see fit to literally THROW AWAY and DESTROY MILLIONS of dollars worth of that costly, (and in the case of LHA-3) still viable steel and technology. The Navy has many truly OLD, no-longer-viable ships it can sink and use for artificial reefs, instead of its sinking such versatile multi-purpose ships as the USS Belleau Wood, a large, relatively young and healthy 27 years old, 40,000-ton amphibious assault ship. The wa$te is truly staggering!! -LHA-3 Rusty, USS Belleau Wood (LHA-3) Plankowner, 1978-1984 R.I.P., USS Belleau Wood!

content: I can tell you that the crown-of-thorns starfish decimates living coral polyps and reef colonies, so the artificial reefs/ships are 'iffy' at best. If the reefs don't form or remain naturally, or are killed off by natural enemies like the crown-of thorns, then the ships are just hulks, home to plants, fish and other denizens of the seas, and places for adventurous scuba divers to explore.
reply: I can tell you that the crown-of-thorns starfish decimates living coral polyps and reef colonies, so the artificial reefs/ships are 'iffy' at best. content: GWG, I agree with you. I inquired about this, the reply was, "It cost more to scrap old ships than sink them as artificial reefs". I suggested they could do as exactly as you said, I recieved no reply. The US trying to be the good guy, buys inferior crap from China and other countries. The steel industry in the states would provide quality steel and employ thousands of American jobs. The steel industry is like others, it's all about PROFIT and GREED. Get cheap labor, screw quality, the fat cats at the top are usless baggage are getting huge incomes, while paying for cheap labor. Fire the fat cats, retain one fat cat, pay him/her an hourly wage. Pay him/ her a few dollars more than those who do the real work! Remember, the recent event of sheet rock purchased from China that was used in new homes? It made people sick and made their homes uninhabitable, once again, profit and greed. Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

title: Sink the Vandenberg!

content: This morning in the Florida waters off Key West, engineers are planting and detonating explosives aboard the U.S.S. Vandenberg, the culmination of almost a decade of legal wrangling, to create a new "artificial reef" for divers to enjoy. I must say I'm pleased on many levels, the least of which being that I am currently in the process of relocating to the Keys for work as a SCUBA Instructor....(I've been teaching SCUBA for 16 years). I am encouraging all certified divers (and if your not certified, THAT little detail can be fixed) to come down and enjoy the new shipwreck and the surrounding reefs that are in the Florida Keys. I would consider it an honor to assist in any way possible, any United States Military Veterans who want to experience the underwater beauty of the Florida Keys.... Please do not take this as a solicitation, for it is not meant to be so. I'm just getting the word out. It's just that SCUBA is my life, and I wholeheartedly believe it's one of the best things a person can persue as a hobby. (Or in my case, a career) See ya in The Keys..... Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI Instructor #160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"

content: Did you ever dive the Spiegel Grove up off of Key Largo near Carysfort Reef? Because the sunk it in such shallow water, they say it's a much more safer dive than the USCG Cutters Bibb or Duane near Molasses Reef. Don USS Spiegel Grove
reply: Did you ever dive the Spiegel Grove up off of Key Largo near Carysfort Reef? Because the sunk it in such shallow water, they say it's a much more safer dive than the USCG Cutters Bibb or Duane near Molasses Reef. Don USS Spiegel Grove

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: Did you ever dive the Spiegel Grove up off of Key Largo near Carysfort Reef? Because the sunk it in such shallow water, they say it's a much more safer dive than the USCG Cutters Bibb or Duane near Molasses Reef. Don I left the Keys for Cabo in March 2000, so I missed the sinking of the Spiegel Grove goin' down....I have dove the U.S.G.C. Duane, the Thunderbolt, The Eagle, and The wreckage of the U.S.S. Alexander, and am WAY STOKED to do them again..... When I was working on the Big Island of Hawaii I spoke to a diver who was present on the dive to the Spiegel Grove when those divers died on it a few years ago, he said the Spiegel was "deceptive and a dive could go bad in a heartbeat (as is the case on any shipwreck if one is not properly trained or careful) and yet I still can't wait to dive it...The U.S.C.G.C Duane is a GREAT dive, (when the conditions are right) and I'm exited as all GET OUT to see a new wreck to go down...Aside from teaching, when it comes to SCUBA, wreck diving is my THING...My ex said I have a screw loose....What do you expect? I'm a SCUBA Instructor... See you at Captain Tony's in Key West! (Or the Green Parrot, or Turtle Kraals, 1st round is on me ! Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI Instructor #160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE USS Spiegel Grove

Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer. The biggest difference is that in the NAUI Openwater I course, a student is taught basic dive rescue(bringing a diver simulating unconciousness to the surface, and initiate rescue breathing) while in the PADI system of diver training that particular exercise is not taught until the Rescue Diver Course....NAUI courses also have a bigger emphasis on snorkeling skills at the surface....Also; during the NAUI divemaster course, a Divemaster candidate is required to do an 880 yd. snorkel with mask, fins, bcd(no tank) and weightbelt in 18 min...The PADI DM course requires an DM candidate to snorkel 800 yds in mask, snorkel, and fins, NO TIME LIMIT..... If you were NAUI certified, it is not necessary to re-certify....You certification should be on file and your card easily replaced just contact NAUI HQ (they are located in Tampa, I believe)...I would highly recommend a refresher course...They are taught at pretty much any dive shop..Regardless of Certification Agency....Hope that helps brah, now dust off the gear AND GO GET WET!!!!! There is another distinction..(some dive instructor humor for you) NAUI= Not Another Underwater Idiot PADI= Pay And Dive Immediately Duane A. Brinson "on the road" U.S.M.C. 1985-1989 PADI#160703 "In the face of terrorism and murder; the call for peace is NOT patriotic, it's COWARDICE"
quote: Originally posted by LHA_3Rusty: NAUI---PADI...what's the difference that makes one supposedly preferable over the other? I was dually certified---by BOTH organizations, and I saw no substantial difference in quality or quantity between either of them. Both were very good. I had active Open Water, Wreck and Cave Diving certs...I let them lapse from living in the dry Arizona desert these last couple of decades and never diving once during that time. Now that I'm going to Panama regularly, I'd like to get re-certified and check out what Panama and other places have to offer.

If you were NAUI certified, it is not necessary to re-certify....You certification should be on file and your card easily replaced just contact NAUI HQ (they are located in Tampa, I believe)...I would highly recommend a refresher course...They are taught at pretty much any dive shop..Regardless of Certification Agency....Hope that helps brah, now dust off the gear AND GO GET WET!!!!! There is another distinction..(some dive instructor humor for you) NAUI= Not Another Underwater Idiot PADI= Pay And Dive Immediately Duane A. title: Sink the Vandenberg!

content: I am still dismayed that DOD/the Navy somehow saw fit to consign the USS Belleau Wood(LHA-3) to the same fate as these other ships; sinking them. The cost to buy foreign steel and to build new ships is climbing fast, yet our lunkhead 'leaders' somehow see fit to literally THROW AWAY and DESTROY MILLIONS of dollars worth of that costly, (and in the case of LHA-3) still viable steel and technology. The Navy has many truly OLD, no-longer-viable ships it can sink and use for artificial reefs, instead of its sinking such versatile multi-purpose ships as the USS Belleau Wood, a large, relatively young and healthy 27 years old, 40,000-ton amphibious assault ship. The wa$te is truly staggering!! -LHA-3 Rusty, USS Belleau Wood (LHA-3) Plankowner, 1978-1984 R.I.P., USS Belleau Wood!

content: I can tell you that the crown-of-thorns starfish decimates living coral polyps and reef colonies, so the artificial reefs/ships are 'iffy' at best. If the reefs don't form or remain naturally, or are killed off by natural enemies like the crown-of thorns, then the ships are just hulks, home to plants, fish and other denizens of the seas, and places for adventurous scuba divers to explore.

content: GWG, I agree with you. I inquired about this, the reply was, "It cost more to scrap old ships than sink them as artificial reefs". I suggested they could do as exactly as you said, I recieved no reply. The US trying to be the good guy, buys inferior crap from China and other countries. The steel industry in the states would provide quality steel and employ thousands of American jobs. The steel industry is like others, it's all about PROFIT and GREED. Get cheap labor, screw quality, the fat cats at the top are usless baggage are getting huge incomes, while paying for cheap labor. Fire the fat cats, retain one fat cat, pay him/her an hourly wage. Pay him/ her a few dollars more than those who do the real work! Remember, the recent event of sheet rock purchased from China that was used in new homes? It made people sick and made their homes uninhabitable, once again, profit and greed. Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
